Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Is there ritual speech?
Comment: During rituals there are things that must be said. But they are said in plain (daily) Wersing.

Feature: Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: It's plain everyday Wersing

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Are there ritual dances?
Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Comment: The languages from neighbouring places are also used. e.g. Kula.

Feature: Do women and men dance together?
Comment: During lego-lego the men and women must stand side by side

Feature: Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Comment: In the past it happened but not now. Rice and meat was offered.

Feature: Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: In Kolana there is an altar

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Comment: It is said they came as a crocodile. Now, if these people lose an object they can call upon the crocodiles to catch the person because they can speak to crocodiles (because their ancestors were crocodile)

Feature: Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: They, for some reason, kept avoiding telling the tale (crocodile above) and I could not keep pressing. Perhaps because they feel they know where they came from i.e. Pantar and that's enough.

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Comment: The king is the leader of tradition.

Feature: Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: Food: Tembakau iris, daun koi (lontar), sirih pinang. Drinks: Tuak/sopi

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment: Like an altar where all the warriors and the king gather and shoot and arrow to sacrifice the animal.

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: couldn't get the Wersing expression but the translation is: "satu minggu kokok keluar". One week after the birth of a child, they throw a big party where they shave the child's hair. Now this doesn't happen anymore. The priest comes to pray for the child.

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: To the wood gatherers that will make the coffin, the family of the deceased will hold a ritual where they offer tools, sopi, rice and meat (pork) and charge them to find the wood needed to make the coffin. Words: boŋkoŋ boŋ lur boŋ kwai kul spir a mai ne pəri mətiarrɛŋ "Go look for wood, straight or bent, make a ship (coffin) and come back to us". When they come back with the coffin, they give more gifts.

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: But I don't know them because it's so long ago. It doesn't happen now. From what I know, when it is harvest season, they gather and sing while holdings hands, they stomp on the rice grains together to clean it of the husks. It is gathered and cooked to feed people.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Comment: It follows the ancestors designs

Feature: Is there traditional pottery?
Comment: In the past we made those but no more.

Feature: Are there moko?
Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Comment: Mokos are not made and they cannot be repaired once broken. It's not the metal we know here.

Feature: Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: gong, tambourines, and a flute made of bamboo played to the side of the face called bakwal. It has six holes (like a flute). It was traditionally used to welcome kings.

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Comment: It's the same style for Wersing Kula and Sawila, but when you go out to the Klon people it's not the same. The difference is the beat/rythmn of the gong

Feature: Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: People still do it now. We do it to impress people. It is seen as beautiful. The ritual is to kill a chicken and give rice to the one doing the filing. The filing must happen in pairs, with both getting filed. The pair doesn't have to be married or have any special relationship other than both wanting their teeth filed.

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Traditional piercings?
Comment: In the past there used to be clips only used for kings made of gold to clip in the ear. Now we make piercings.

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: They have necklaces made of muti (beads). It is not made, but said to be given by the devils. Feathers are used in the head, and rotan.

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: The women wear ankle bracelets made of metals "kəriŋ kəriŋ" which makes sounds as they dance or stomp their feet.

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: Cloth, waistband, headgear, sword are all used during ceremonies.

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: wudi pes 'sun rise' = east, wudi teiŋ 'sun fall' = west. ligəlol = north, alol = south. Wherever you are, you always know where east is facing.

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Comment: It just follows the sun.

Feature: Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Several languages are spoken here. Where I come from (Peitoko) there are 3: Kula, Wersing, Subola (?). Everyone understands one another while speaking their own languages. e.g. a Kula speaker speaks to me in Kula, I understand and reply in Wersing. In Maritaing (present location) there are 2 languages spoken here: Wersing and Sawila. People can speak their own languages but there is mutual understanding.

Feature: Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: It's quite difficult for children. If a child speaks Sawila, the child will only speak Sawila and does not understand Wersing. When a Sawila child speaks to a Wersing child they will speak in Bahasa Indonesia.

Feature: Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: It is common here.

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: If I marry a Sawila, they will end up speaking Wersing (he notes that she does not learn/study it but will pick it up) because of the environment.

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: As he lives here he will come to a point where he understands the language. The husband and wife will teach other their languages usually.

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: Firstly they speak in Indonesian (after they get married). But after a while they can speak each other's languages

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: Hunt for deer and pigs. Using dogs and bow and arrows.

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: Fish for "ikan karang", "ikan karang" Fishing with a line and nets.

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: Pigs, goats, cows, chickens and ducks too.

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: Dry field cultivation, once a year. Rice, corn and sweet potato and some nuts. The fields are not far away from here. To farm you need to cut the trees, burn the field and then plant.

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Comment: In the past we used to move around. But now because of government rules we now have to stay in one spot to farm. There is no irrigation. There is some in Lantoka though (Kula)

Feature: Major crops?
Comment: Rice, corn and tubers (ubi). The biggest harvest of the year is usually rice and corn.

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: Peitoko has 3 clans, each clan is the head of a traditional house: Sereng no, Ame no, Barabuling. I am from the Sereng no clan. The other speaker is from Barabuling. But we have one blood connection, because my grandmother's female line (ancestor) gave birth to the Barabuling clan.

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: There are specific moeties for each clan. (Moeties are used as last names of people) For Sereng no: Maubara, Manukwei, Takalamakaing. For Barabuling: Retebana, Tubulau, Jobo (The Bupati now is a Jobo). Ame no: Asuba, Kamisioma, Paisera.

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: You can call each clan a 'house' and the moeties (descendants) will gather in that clan/house.

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: There is a King clan (Sereng no). And there are warrior clans (Barabuling and Ame no). The Ame no clan is below the Barabuling clan. Beyond that, at least in the Sereng no clan, the Maubara is of higher rank because it's the eldest one.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Comment: Everyone speaks the same language.

Feature: Is real property (land) inherited?
Comment: Property (houses) and land is inherited.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: Parents give them to the children as they please

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: There were people in the past that owned the land (e.g. Land lord). He was the first person who lived in the land. But over the years that land was split and given to different people. We had to give the landlord a portion of our harvest every year. But in the 50s and 60s it stopped.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: Inheritance is for all, given by the parents while they are alive. When women marry, by right they leave the family to join her husband. However, if they return to ask for a share of the inheritance, it will be given to her because it is her right by blood. If parents pass away, everyone discusses what to do.

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Comment: If my sister dies, my family does not get the inheritance, it will go to her children (and vice versa)

Feature: Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Comment: But daughters can get it too if they ask for it.

Feature: Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Comment: But daughters can get it too if they ask for it.

Feature: Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Comment: Yes

Feature: Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: There are 2 types of foreigners: there are those that just want to just buy land. And there are those who join our village because they have ties to the members in the village.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: It depends on the individual, about 20-25 years old for the boys. For girls about 17-18 years old. In the past, girls had to be able to weave (tenun) before you could get married and the boys usually had to work before getting married. But now as long as you are done with school you can get married.

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: People of the same clan cannot get married. People of different clans can get married as long as their family name is different. In the case of the speakers, the Maubara's son cannot marry the Barabuling's daughter because it goes against the order of things. A plant that has sprouted, its tips cannot return to the tree/root. This is because the Barabuling took a Maubara daughter already (seed was planted).

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: Nowadays couples will exhange rings but this is not our culture, and just newly added.

Feature: Is there bride service?
Comment: In the past, if the man liked the woman, they lived in the house of the woman and worked as a servant for a number of years (anywhere from 1-2 to even 5-6 years) until he pays the brideprice. If  he cannot do so, he loses his surname and takes up the woman's surname "balik marga"/"kawin masuk". E.g. I am a Tubulau, my Wife is a Maubara. If I couldn't pay, I would have to change my name to a Maubara.

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: The couple needs to live independently. You need to have a house in order to marry. But if there really is no house, they usually stay in the husband's old residence.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Comment: If you don't have a house you live with groom's parents first but you must build a house.

Feature: Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
Comment: You cannot marry within a clan. But there have been cases where you are from the same clan but have different surnames and that was permitted.

Feature: If mother dies, who raises the children?
Comment: The father takes care of the children, and if both die, the parents will. If the father dies, and the woman can still marry. they might marry her again, but it is up to the husband's family since she already entered that family through marriage. It is very possible to marry the late groom's brother.
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Comment: There is this term: Bini rumah suami rumah

Feature: Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Comment: It's free. We can even marry in America.

Feature: Was polygamy permitted
Comment: In the past, the king could marry up to 2 or 3 times. But not for commoners.

Feature: Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: belis = moko from the bridegroom to the bride. Food or animals are brought in for the feast (not as a bridewealth) for everyone to enjoy.

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: When the groom provides the moko, the bride returns the payment with material goods such as blankets, sarungs (woven cloths), clothes, plates, furniture, and everything else required for their new lives as a family.

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: Permanent homes with roads runing through.

Feature: Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: No. Even if someone wanted to live apart they couldn't because they belong to the village and as such need to live in the village together with everyone else.

Feature: Are settlements permanent?
Comment: In the past they used to have semi-permanent settlements because wars that broke out between the Wersing clans as well as with neighbouring Kula and Sawila clans. But now people are generally settled, although the younger children have decided to travel outside of Alor (e.g. Jakarta) and live there.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Comment: You build a house where you can.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Comment: Seaside/coastal villages

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Comment: Both in Lantoka and Peitoko

Feature: Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: There is the "gudang" or traditional house where the men meet to discuss issues. There is also an altar "mesbah" where you perform rituals such as the lego-lego

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Comment: Rectangular layout with 4 pillars. (It cannot be square). Speaker claims that these characteristic traditional houses in the village is not Wersing (?) and people in the past lived in walled houses on the ground made of woven bamboo. The traditional houses are from the Kula and Sawila clans. The reason being the Wersing in the past did not farm fields and instead fished for a living. They bartered their fish, seasalt and crafts (e.g. kain tenun) for corn and rice with the people from the mountain who had tradtitional huts as a place to store dry grains. Now we have these houses. In the old times they used to have a traditional house (no mention on how it looks like) and each clan had their own houses. e.g. sereng no literally means 'east house' because the wersing come from Timor Leste (East Leste).

Feature: Floor level of traditional houses?
Comment: Bamboo walls and floors, roof is made from alang-alang. Raised platform from the ground.

Feature: Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Comment: Pyramid shaped made from alang-alang traditionally (but it can be made of corrugated sheets of metal).

Feature: Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Comment: Storage of e.g. corn, gading, moko

Feature: Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: The leader of the clan can be hereditary but it could also be someone from outside the family line.

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Comment: The clan leader is chosen through a consensus of gathered elders/members of the community. It's usually clear who the next leader will be, so an election is not necessary.

Feature: Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: In the past, perhaps 700 years ago

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: It's generally the same.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Comment: It is possible, but does not happen often.

Feature: Are there men’s houses
Comment: Rumah adat belongs to men to sit and talk about adat. (women sit behind or outside)

Feature: Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: The title of king 'raja adat' is inherited by the descendants of a particular lineage, usually it's the first born male. However, in the case where there are no more descendants, a woman can also be called to be a clan leader. If there are no more descendants, that's the end of that line.

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: Hereditary, coming from one family

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Comment: Leri is king, doesn't matter from where.

Feature: Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: Peitoko has relations with this village (Kolana), the Sawila and Kula people. There are traditional rituals where they are present. There are also mounds made by ancestors who formed these alliances.

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Comment: The belabaja in peitoko stretches to the Kula people of the mountain. The alliance is called "sump".

Feature: Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: Everyone can name the child (parents, grandparents, family).
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Comment: Generally your traditional name can indicate strongly of which family line you descend from. e.g. laku ser is a name that must be from the Maubara line/ Kaimlai (sp?) is a given name that is from Tubulau line

Feature: Are names taken from the father's group?
Are names taken from the mother's group?
Are there name taboos?
Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
Comment: Anyone older than you (generational sense). You need to call them by their proper titles. You cannot call your parent in-law by name.

Feature: did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment: The language does not have another name, but someone speaking Wersing is called ɔlba. This is a term well-known in Alor so if hear on the street someone being called ɔlba he is probably Wersing. He also claims that you can call Wersing "Bahasa Kolana" (Kolana being the location that is the easternmost coast of Alor. Currently a mix of Sawila and Wersing people)

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: "baniak"
